utterance: Ana Bento, Indiana University: Pilar was saying, but I I think we cannot start talking about transmission chain without thinking about the pathogen or the infectious agent first, I suppose, before going for a kind of like abstract uh discussion on that. Um but kind of like susceptibility is is is kind of like the second biggest part I suppose because then that affects both whatever reservoir or whatever vector and whatever host we might have.

annotations.expand on existing idea: The speaker builds on the initial point by adding that understanding susceptibility is also crucial, as it affects the reservoir, vector, and host, expanding on the factors to consider in transmission dynamics.

utterance: Matt Erdman - USDA APHIS: So you're talking about host susceptibility?

annotations.ask clarifying question: Matt is asking Ana to confirm if she is referring to 'host susceptibility' to ensure he understands her point about the infectious agent and susceptibility in relation to transmission chains.

utterance: Ana Bento, Indiana University: Uh yes. Or or vector susceptibility depending on as Pilar was very well saying, you know, depending on what kind of uh mode of transmission, I guess we would call it, then susceptibility is kind of like a necessary condition for a transmission chain to occur.

annotations.explain or define term or concept: The speaker defines susceptibility as a necessary condition for a transmission chain to occur, clarifying its role in the context of the discussion.
annotations.expand on existing idea: The speaker builds on the previous discussion about host susceptibility by adding vector susceptibility and explaining how it relates to the mode of transmission.

utterance: Pilar Fernandez (WSU, she/her): Yeah, and then it I guess going back on that, then you're going to have dead ends. Um and there you're going to have some uh hosts that are not going to contribute to onward transmission. So the pathogen kind of like dies there under certain conditions whether it's because that um because of a behavior that um host cannot pass it on to another host or because let's say if it's a human, they go to the hospital and they cannot pass it on. So it's like what's the contribution to onward transmission and to maintaining that transmission chain. Um we can also think about that.

annotations.expand on existing idea: Pilar expands on the idea of transmission chains and susceptibility, building on Ana's previous points about the importance of considering the pathogen and host susceptibility by introducing the concept of 'dead ends' in transmission.

utterance: Joyce Jose, Penn State: Uh dead end host that could be termed to.

utterance: Pilar Fernandez (WSU, she/her): It doesn't contribute to onward transmission. Uh and and and that's very like we can think about that also in a gradient. It can be uh it stops there. There's no onward transmission or they could be I don't know, let's say it's less infectious. So the probability of passing it to another host is it's diminished.

utterance: Joyce Jose, Penn State: Yeah.

utterance: Matt Hopken (USDA-APHIS-NWRC): I'm just working on that happened to be working with rabies. And so like a horse gets infected with rabies, but a horse is not going to transmit it. And so the virus at that point virus population goes extinct in that host.

utterance: Ana Bento, Indiana University: That's perversely cool when we think about spillovers because that happens every day. Spillovers happen into these dead end hosts that then don't actually, you know, create the transmission chain onwards in their own population or even into other species. Um which is super cool. Um in a weird way.

utterance: Matt Hopken (USDA-APHIS-NWRC): Well, I also think another component of a transmission chain is um opportunity, which susceptibility plays into that, but also the overlapping of the pathogen, vector and host in both space and time. annotations.provide supporting evidence: Matt supports his idea by explaining that the overlapping of pathogen, vector, and host in space and time is necessary for the transmission chain to take off.

utterance: Pilar Fernandez (WSU, she/her): Yeah, and and just to add the spatial component to that, one of the things that I'm I'm really interested in um is that we know that for example in rural areas, maybe those opportunities for overlap or those spillover events to occur may happen with a higher probability, but the actual probability of an outbreak uh might not be there just because there's not enough people around or the other conditions or beyond being detected or not detected, I'm not even like without taking into consideration access to healthcare and having actually detected, but just because of a human density, uh it might not you might not actually get an outbreak.

utterance: Pilar Fernandez: Yeah, and and on that I can tell you a story. I my work is very interdisciplinary because I'm trying to combine the the social dimension um and trying to understand that. So I've worked with economists, I've worked with um sociologist and most of my work on doing my PhD was in rural communities. And one of the things that we were not really paying attention to was the human movement or that it was a very cultural aspect. Uh so there was indigenous communities in the Gran Chaco region, which is really interesting if we talk about anthropogenic change because that's at the expansion of the agricultural frontier. So there's a lot of deforestation, human displacement happening. But one of the things that caught us our attention, we were like doing yearly uh entomological surveys to collect triatomines. And from one year to the next, people will move. Like they literally destroy their house, they're mud houses and build them somewhere else. We're like, we could not not find the house to do like a longitudinal surveillance. And and then we understood that it was just a cultural thing. It was also enhanced by the socio economic conditions. Um but it they were semi nomadic communities. So you cannot and that had a huge impact on the population of the vector because you didn't give enough time for the vector to um create high densities. But on the other side, you create really um the house are very precarious, so more opportunities for any bug outside bug to invade and have an infestation in that house. So it had a really interesting tradeoff just on without even thinking about how people get exposed to it, just on the vector population. And we were not really thinking about that because culturally to us it's like, well, you've been in this house, you're at least going to be there for a couple years. Uh but they would move frequently. And so we started working with sociologists trying to understand why because if we want to do an intervention and design an intervention strategy to spray the houses, we need to take into account that movement because it's not the same if you're spraying a house and it's going to last for the effect is going to last for this long, whether it's like, no, it's not going to last because in three months they're going to be somewhere else. Um so yeah, I do think that's a really key part of it and that's kind of what it actually drove my interest in trying to incorporate the human, the cultural and behavioral aspects.

annotations.provide supporting evidence: Pilar provides a detailed story about her interdisciplinary work in rural communities, specifically focusing on indigenous communities in the Gran Chaco region and their semi-nomadic lifestyle, to support the idea that cultural and behavioral aspects are crucial for understanding disease transmission and designing effective intervention strategies, building on the previous discussion about the importance of human behavior and cultural factors in outbreak response.

utterance: Matt Hopken: Yeah, and I would like to add all of this is great discussion. It seems to all be interconnected and I would like to add going back initially what was talking about and some others is like this interface area where you have livestock, wildlife, humans coming into contact. I feel like one of the shortcomings here is is some type of early detection system, right? As as the pathogens are moving into these habitats whether it's through environmental change, we've now created an environment where domestic species like can now move into that area where they previously didn't or we've increased human populations in these areas but or we've increased livestock deforestation and then growing livestock in these areas. Um we don't know what's happening as we're cutting down these trees and changing these ecosystems, what types of pathogens, what types of threats are actually there and we're often reactive. Oh now we see the the infections are happening but it's already too late at that point because it's already kind of taken off or got the snowball effect. But the development and this is probably futuristic but some type of technological advancement that allows us to early detect in these interface systems threats. And I don't know what those are but I'm just throwing out Star Trek type ideas of where we could go with this in the future.
